title: What if peace isn't found by controlling your circumstances?
teaser: 43% of adults are more anxious than last year. The news is relentless. What if safety isn't the goal?

panels.heading: THE RELENTLESS SCROLL
panels.content:
You wake up and reach for your phone. Check the news. Check the markets. Check the weather, the traffic, the COVID numbers, the political headlines.

By 8 AM, you've consumed a day's worth of anxiety.

43% of adults felt more anxious in 2024 than the year before. The number keeps climbing. 53% are anxious about

You're not imagining it. The dread is real.

And you've tried everything to make it stop.

panels.heading: THE MYTH OF CONTROL
panels.content:
You thought if you just stayed informed enough, planned enough, prepared enough—you'd feel safe.

So you optimize. Morning routines. Meditation apps. Therapy. Doomscrolling breaks. You stockpile canned goods, bookmark survival guides, rehearse worst-case scenarios in your head.

You're building walls against the chaos. Higher, thicker, stronger.

But the storms keep coming.

Because here's the truth you don't want to hear: **You can't control the world. You were never supposed to.**

And the harder you try, the more exhausted you become.

Safety isn't the goal. It's the prison.

panels.heading: THE COST OF THE FORTRESS
panels.content:
The cost of trying to control everything is this: **you stop living.**

You can't enjoy a meal without calculating calories. You can't watch the news without spiraling. You can't make plans without the caveat

Your body keeps the score. Tight shoulders. Clenched jaw. Insomnia. Burnout.

You've made your life a fortress. But you're trapped inside.

And the thing you're most afraid of—losing control—has already happened.

You never had it to begin with.

The question is: what do you do with that?

illustration.description: Dithered ink drawing of person building walls around themselves OR fortress crumbling

panels.heading: AN ANCIENT LETTER TO THE ANXIOUS
panels.content:
2,000 years ago, a man named Paul wrote a letter to a community drowning in anxiety.

They were under Roman occupation. Political violence everywhere. Economic exploitation. Daily survival was uncertain.

Sound familiar?

And Paul—who'd been beaten, shipwrecked, imprisoned for his beliefs—wrote this:

**

**Do not be anxious.**

Impossible, right?

Keep reading.

panels.heading: THE DIFFERENT KIND OF ANCHOR
panels.content:
He says: **peace that transcends understanding will guard your heart.**

Not the absence of storm.

A different kind of anchor.

Peace isn't found by controlling your circumstances.

It's found by surrendering control to the One who holds all things.

panels.heading: THE INVITATION
panels.content:
God,

I've been building walls, trying to control what I can't.

I'm exhausted. The news is relentless. My body is tight with fear.

I don't know how to stop being anxious. But you do.

Teach me the peace that doesn't make sense. The kind that exists even in the storm.

Guard my heart when I can't guard myself.

I'm ready to stop building fortresses.

Amen.
